It's a cute place, but the fireplace for which I came is a paltry thing. Looks fake with some sort of pearlized plastic cover which is intended to add to the illusion of fire I guess. Onward to something better I think.
author: E R.

description:
So, my friend said, "have you been to the bar with the white elephant above it?" I said, "what?!"

When we finally found the location, and after I ridiculed my friend for thinking a horse looks like a cow (midwesterners should know better, right?), I was pleasantly surprised by this dark wood tavern. Brian, the bartender, was quite nice and a refreshingly warm person. 

Nothing too special to report about the drinks, it's booze, you can't really screw it up. But what got me was the atmosphere, I felt as though I was in an old tavern in the English countryside, with a crackling fireplace and all wooden furniture. Very comfy! I'll definitely go back for a relaxing cocktail and conversation with friends.
author: Lauren J.

description: Great neighborhood spot to grab a beer and catch up with a friend.  Came here for just those reasons and was not disappointed.  It has a British pub feel, comfy stools, free popcorn, and hotdogs until 9 and shuffle board!!  Yay for games, beer and yummy bar food!
author: Sarah C.

description: This bar has an old style feel to it.  The selection on tap is small so don't come for beer.  Come for old comfort and shots.
author: Byron L.

description: The beer was good but the bartender makes you feel like she's doing you a favor. Sorry worked 12 years in restaurants. "Ain't nobody got time for that"!   Enjoy your job...
author: Geno B.

description: Wish this place wasn't so packed. We went at 10pm on a Saturday and couldn't get a seat. In the backroom there was a group of 20 people that didn't leave much room for a small group on us. I LOVED the layout, the decor and the vibe. Next time I'm back in SF, I'll give it another whirl.
author: Sarah C.

description: Asked the worker for an ATM and he barked at me to go to another location. I followed the advice and won't be back here 100% sure. Thanks.
author: Craig B.

description:
No sign of life- permanently closed?
Jan 16, 2014.
author: Johnny R.

description: We came here after reading Yelp reviews about the steaks as we were in the mood for steak but didnt ant to spend a fortune. We never got our steak because the bartender told us the resturant was closed for renovations. We had to go elsewhere. The two stars is because the place is charming looking, but I was most irritated that their poor website never said anything about the restaurant being closed.  I think there is an obligation to one's customers to do this!
author: Linda L.

description:
Oh, yes...

A very convenient bar to hop to after a dog day's work. 

Free hot dogs? (Good for those who like to nosh...give me more beer, please...)

Popcorn? (Yeah, I'll dig on that.)

Wanna feel the comfort of drinking with your parents?? (You gotta admit, sometimes you miss home...there's a 50+ vibe, for sure.)

Fantasies about dragging the dude you're dating to have sex in the bathroom????!!!! (In this case you could, b/c it's an old hotel room. Plenty of space to get some....oh, and clean!!) 

Oooh...that might be weird if you're 'drinking with your parents'. But who didn't sneak a bf home?

Yeah, I'll go with, "I love you, White Horse"....just gotta go home first. And make sure I meet that dude.

Ha!
author: Elle N M.

description: Great find near Union square. Looks like small uk pub. Cheap eats with $5 beer. Fish n chips and burgers all good. Service prompt n polite. Affordable in sf good fine
author: Beach G.

description: This place is sweet. Reasonable price drinks and friendly staff. Reminds me of the time I went to a tavern back in 1796. Only difference is there's a popcorn machine which you can just help yourself to. Back in my day we had to use a cast iron kettle and open flames, which they frown upon now.
author: Raul S.

description: My girlfriend and I were walking around SF and we decided to check this bar out on a lark. It has a fantastically laid back ambiance and decent prices for the City.
author: Forrest P.

description:
Service - 6
Atmosphere - 8
Food - 5
Vegetarian Friendly - 5
General Awesomeness - 9

Any bar that serves free hot dogs is a friend of mine! (although I don't eat meat, I do fully support giving away hotdogs to patrons!)  Throwing some old muskets and a cross bow on the wall make up for the lack of a great beer selection.
author: Buford M.

description: My daughter and I had a great time. Interesting conversations with fellow patrons and especially Steve, the bartender.
author: cv b.

description: This is a great hangout on Sutter Street with an "English pub" theme.  We stopped in a couple of times this weekend - the bartender was friendly, there was a nice (but not loud) crowd present, and the drinks were cheap. They even had free hot dogs with all the fixings.  We'll definitely go back on our next trip to SF!
author: Jennifer J.

description: We stayed at the Cartwright hotel while In SF And this little place was right across the street. Our waitress was very friendly and let you seat yourselves . we ordered the steak and the brick pressed chicken. They both were fairly large portions and came with garlic mashed potatoes and Brussel sprouts. The steak was very good and and well seasoned but the chicken was a little bland and Boring. The mashed potatoes were very good! Also, I would warn against ordering soda there it had a very odd taste something might be wrong with their machine. Overall a good time plus free popcorn!
author: Livvy B.

description: Was hoping to try the food. Bar looked nice. Old east coast feeling. One star being kitchen remodeling going on.
author: Scott S.

description: This was an older pub, had an English feel to it.  I  had a great time here, lots to look at.
author: Emily H.

description:
I love the decor here!  It reminds me of stumbling into a small pub in the English countryside.  The bar is attached to an old style hotel (think The Shining, but not creepy), and the bathrooms are located in empty, out of use hotel rooms.  It's neat to see the inside of the hotel.

Beer - only Stella and Bass on tap when we were there - is decently priced at $4 a pint, which is almost unheard of nowadays.  

I hate to sound like an old fogie, but Friday night may not be the best time to visit, depending on your mood.  There were quite a few Academy of Art students and young backpackers from the hotel, which detracted a bit from the charm.
author: Pearl L.

description: Haha, lovely dive. Free popcorn, yum. Good space for large groups in the back. Bathroom seems a little complicated because its attached to the hotel. Small local crowd. Games on the tv in the front. Don't order an Old English when you mean Old Fashioned, the bartender will give you a look of death!
author: Naomi K.

description:
This English-style tavern has great ambiance and a great whisky selection.  The beer selection is very limited (3 or 4 local brews) but very good.  No loud background music, so it's a great place to have a conversation.

I don't know why it's called a "restaurant".  When I've been there sure they serve only drinks.
author: A R.

description: This rustic, comfy tavern has been our favorite place to hangout when we visit SF for more than 30 years.  No fancy bar foods. Giant hot dogs, popcorn , and a convivial bar. Very early US feel.  You expect to see Paul Revere stop in for an ale.
author: Karen F.

description: Had drinks after a friend's production at the Phoenix Theater. Warm atmosphere with great drinks. Loved it!
author: Tracy A.

description:
Went there last night to have a couple drinks with friends. First time there, and all I knew about it was that Don Draper himself went to a White Horse on a Mad Men episode.

Place was quiet when we arrived, with the exception of a table of older people a few seats away and some stragglers at the bar. English-style pub/tavern- small, simple, rustic. It seems like one of those places that either is super low key or, on the rare occasion, gets a crowd. Granted, a wedding party came in last night so the place was out of control. I'd totally recommend trying it for a drink or to bring a group of friends that can sit in the banquette area in the back. Me and my boyfriend drank 5 drinks, that being Old Fashioned's and G&T's. spent about $50.

Points of interest: Free movie-style popcorn and hot dogs.

All you can do is try it and see what kind of night it ends up becoming. I'll definitely go back, and hopefully have a better sense of the place so I can write a more knowledgeable review.
author: Michelle L.

description:
As a frequent traveler to London I looked forward to having a pint or two at the White Horse with my gal pal Lori. I thought I read that there was a restaurant so I planned to also have dinner only to be told by the friendly bar tender that the kitchen was closed but free hotdogs and popcorn were being offered; not exactly the beef roast with Yorkshire pudding I had on my mind.

They serve two draught beers, Bass Ale and Stella Artois, I chose the Bass Ale. The music changed dramatically throughout the evening and the place began to fill up about 7p'ish. It's a cozy place with several tables for two and a faux fireplace to give you that English Countryside feeling.

They do take credit cards so you can easily run a tab.

P.s. the dogs were great but a spiced mustard vs. American mustard would have been perfect. The popcorn was stale!
author: David P.

description: Cool little pub in sf,  nice bartender and locals, have liquor too, was surprised, thought only a beer wine place.  I'll be back
author: Jon B.

description:
Been here a couple times with friends after dinner/drinks elsewhere. We've always had a cool hang here; the bartenders are nice, free popcorn (!), and it's just a cool little dive bar in Nob Hill.

Also, the other people drinking there have been really cool in my experience. Just nice people, and no douchebags. In this city, that's always a plus. ;)
author: Paige E.

description: Fun little gay bar, but straighteys are welcome too. Gets hopping late at night. Best for Thurs/Fri/Sat evenings. STRONG drinks, friendly bouncer and bartenders, cover on weekends. Even has a smoking porch with heaters.
author: Anne H.

description:
Went here for the first time this past Saturday. Was staying with some friends just up the street, after a long day of walking around the city this was the perfect place to wind down. As soon as I walked in I loved the decor, the lighting in quite dim, loved the muskets on the wall, and wooden interior. Bartenders were very nice, greeted me as soon as I stepped in the door. Beers on tap a good, although they is not many to select from. Seems like they have a wide selection of whiskey that I will have to check out next time I am there. Noise level was pretty low which was good because I was with a large group of friends and wanted to carry a conversation without yelling. Music was on pretty low, I was surprised to hear Bob Marley play a few times. I thoroughly enjoyed the free popcorn, and although there were no hot dogs that night I hear they do serve them from time to time. Huge plus for me was the shuffle board table, had a lot of fun playing a few rounds. 

All in all I had a wonderful low key night here, will definitely be visiting next time I am up north. 

Oh yes, last note. They did have  a TV or two, but I was quite refreshed to see that they were turned off.
author: Feliz M.

description:
All you need to know about this place is:

The crowd: Half hotel mob (it's a hotel pub, actually), half Art students. Interesting mix, surely. Just throw yourself in there and, after the first few scrutinizing glares and quizzical looks, you'll be fine -- I promise. 

The atmosphere: Awkward. Pub. 

The food: Ha! If you can call it that. But you know what? It's free. Yes, free. Free popcorn -- GASP. Free hot dogs and condiments -- CAN'T BE. It's true. Of course, they might not be up to par with certain tastes, but for me it does the trick when I'm gulping down beer and need something to put in there to stop the crashing of a pintful on an otherwise empty stomach. 

The service: Dry as a camel's bumb. But the bartender tends the bar, and that's all that I'm asking for.

The drinks: $4 Stella. In San Francisco. Not half baaaad.

Overall: it'll do on a Wednesday afternoon !!!
author: G. J.

description: We held our reception at the Marines Memorial Club on the same block as the White Horse. We came in here both nights, after rehearsal dinner and after reception. This is a great dive bar. Prices are reasonable, we could squeeze a lot of people in here and they didn't give us a hard time for bringing quite a few boozy people in. Bartenders were nice...good spot in Union Square.
author: Sarah L.

description:
A strange set of circumstances led me to this pub. The first thing I noticed were three hand pumps right on the front of the bar, I was very happy to see them. I asked the bartender what they had on the hand pumps and she said they didn't work. Either they are fakes or not hooked up but either way it's pathetic. The only beers they actually had on tap were Bass and I think Pilsner so I had Anchor steam in a bottle.

The place is trying too hard to be a stereotypical English pub without delivering. The bartender was very friendly though.
author: Manny F.

description:
Cheap drinks, tons of pretzels, plenty of places to sit - exactly what was needed for the wedding afterparty.

Did we need any of the above (except the place to sit)? No.

Did that stop us? Not at all.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place makes me laugh. Its almost creepy inside, reminds me of a bar you would find in a Harry Potter movie with talking pictures and dark wood, creaking floors. 
The bartender has his area up front where you can order your beverage and then sit as far back as you desire, the place is pretty big. 
Should you be craving a hot dog at any point they serve FREE hot dogs with the purchase of any beverage daily until 9 PM. Therefore, the whole place smells like hot dogs. 
After 9 PM. they provide pop corn which is nice for those of us that don't like hot dogs. 
While you are sipping on your cocktail I would encourage you to take advantage of the Shuffle Board game in the back- its authentic and fun. 
Beware- my only gripe is the bathroom situation. There was not an official bathroom so they converted two guest rooms in the Beresford Hotel next door for a men's/women's lou. It is rather creepy to walk in to an empty, gutted guest room and use a bathroom- just sayin'.
author: Janell D.

description:
Can we please make a note that this damn place has been closed for months, even though I keep calling to see if they're open so I can grab food here?
Oh, I guess I just did.
Well, I've only been in once for drinks, and thought it was nice enough but in need of a face lift.  HURRY UP AND LIFT PLEASE.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Having finally dined at White Horse, I'll admit they earn the fifth star.  The food was outstanding and really inexpensive.  I ordered a  lamb shank special that was big enough for two people, yet less than $20 and still makes my mouth water when I think back on it.  The fillet Mignon for which they are famous met expectations, and someone ordered a fish dish which was cherished as well.  

Our server was sweet, yet salty (I think she was our bartender the first time we tried to eat here), and my only complaint is the way it looks in the dining room.  Clearly, they haven't remodeled or redecorated in decades and the 1960s hunting lodge isn't where I would want to bring a date or anyone else I was trying to impress.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I just so much love this place. Its so cozy and friendly. I love coming here with my sweetie and having out martini's. We have not yet tryed  thier cookin but from what I was told and smell the food is tobe really good. I will update on the food next time. 

THis is for sure a treat to try out.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Upon first sitting down, my teenage brother looks around, leans across the table, and whispers "This place smells like old people."

That's not necessarily a bad thing. Sure it's a total time warp of a trip back to a different time, but it's a place I could definitely see bringing my grandparents. Lots of mahogany and lace, with standard dishes at quality prices.

I had the filet mignon dinner for $17.95 (!), which was served with chive mashed potatoes and steamed green beans and carrots. The meat was delicious, and the sides serviceable but certainly not write-home worthy. But for $18, the meal is definitely something my frugal older relatives would be ALL about. I also had the cream of asparagus soup, which was perfectly seasoned and wonderful. 

It's a small restaurant (probably no more than 20 people could eat here at a time) operated by 1-2 servers at peak hours, so service can be a leeeetle slow, although quite accommodating. 

By the end of dinner, my mom and I surmised that my brother's original observation was a bit off. A group of 4 or so couples sat down that looked and talked in such a way that made us believe that White Horse is actually the PERFECT place for the following sort of individual:
http://video.aol.com/partner/hulu/saturday-night-live-patio-lovers/2ON5hJesYxS6q0fONU-UahepnLXublEF
author: Devon S.

description:
Okay, so I'm not a local, but in my week long stay in San Fran, I did visit many bars and restaurants. 

Normally, I'm all about dive bars, and honestly, this is a nice dive. I came in with my friend after a long night of shopping and bar hopping. It was drizzley and freezing, needless to say, we needed a place to duck into and warm up.

Anyway, we were greeted by a sweet bartender with a jolly demeanor and goofy tie. The place was warm and full of people, yet there were still many free tables. 

One thing that I liked was how it felt as though I stepped out of a large city and into an old pub out in a countryside...not an Americanized pub at that, mind you.

I'm giving it a 3 star rating because I just came in here once and although the bartender seemed very sweet, the drink was kind of vile (we ordered 2 hot buttered rum drinks)..not my usual, so I feel it unfair to score them any lower because i really want to like this place.

Another think I couldn't quite get over was the foul stench in there. It smelled like old, stale beer...kind of like the morning after a huge frat party...or so I'd imagine. Again, I'm not sure if this was an isolated incident or not. I really hope it was.

A plus is definitely the munchies they provide. I saw people asking for bowls of nuts and would see the bartender fill bowls with nuts and all sorts of party mix goodies free of charge. Pretty cool.

Would I visit again? Definitely. Mainly to see if my sub-par experience was a fluke and would be able to rate them higher next time. I really would like that because like i said, this place seems so welcoming and a perfect way to end a very busy day...also, the bartender can pour some pretty strong drinks..just don't ask for a buttered rum. xP
author: sabi b.

description:
Dinner Hi-lights:
- friendly service
- Old World ambiance
- quiet, so you can chat without straining
- asparagus soup + complimentary sourdough bread
- prices reasonable

Dinner Lo-lights:
- salad was doused with vinaigrette, fried goat cheese so-so
- linguine was fair too.

***

I'd rather go back for just drinks next time.  Though my ol' friend once told me he really enjoys the breakfasts here.
author: Cathy K.

description: On my jaunt to SF in 1965, this is where we stayed.  The five stars are for the memories......the hotel is still there, but I don't know how it is now......the lobby looks good!  OK, the memories:  my friend, Peggy, and I hitched to SF from Boulder on our spring break.  We picked up 3 guys and brought them to our room at the Beresford, where we drank a 50-cent gallon of wine & crashed on the floor (no funny business).   I think the room cost  $6 a night, and that was a whole lot of money, so we didn't have food.  I remember passing around a single can of tuna on that night at the hotel.  Our new friends also brought something else to pass around.......if my Son is reading this:  I didn't have any.  I was the only teenager in the sixties who didn't smoke pot, believe it.
author: Joan S.

description: I'll get to the point. We held our book club meeting at the White Horse last Thursday. Great atmosphere. That block isn't too sketchy at 7:00 pm. And the food was wonderful! Our group of seven tried a wide selection of entrees and apps: tomato and dill soup was the du'jour, two gals split the lamb shanks, a meatloaf, warm goat cheese salad (also split), we hit all the high points. Everything faboo! Except ... the lone waitress felt a little hassled when a member of our small'ish party (only seven of us) asked for another glass of water for the second time. She snapped. It was embarrasing and uncalled for and put a pallor on the good time. So just be sensitive, as always, to the wait staff.
author: Bronwyn W.

description: Wanted a place to have a few beers and talk, this place was perfect. We played shuffleboard and enjoyed the complimentary popcorn and hot dogs! Great place!
author: Dustin M.

description: A very cool spot with personality and nice barkeeps.  We spent New Years Eve here and the only downer was the terrible music they were playing.  Nirvana at 5 til midnight?  The popcorn is yum, the shuffleboard keeps gamers entertained.  Hiddem gem.
author: e w.

description:
Yep, uh-huh. this place is rad.
Character is practically dripping out of its plug-in fireplace, ancient wooden Anglophilia-decor and the seasoned bartender Saul.
The fillet mignon was tasty and my drink was strong. Another point (or pint) for the TenderNob.
author: Julia T.

description: Walked in wanting dinner but turns out they werent serving food. Thats why this is only getting 3 stars. The bartender was super friendly and recommended a place just down the road. It seemed very inviting tho.
author: Sarah S.

description:
We had a great experience here! It's charming and cozy enough for a date but cool enough to meet friends for drinks too! 

Both of our entrees were excellent, wine was great, they even has hot buttered rum! Great value too. Service was excellent. Also enjoyed the music, 1940's style.
author: Allison C.

description:
Great prices on drinks. Stupendous bartender. Free hot dogs!

There are only two beers on tap, but those two are Stella and Bass, which make a good enough selection for one night.
author: Yod S.

description:
A gem in the Nob.  
I prefer bars like this; ones with history and character.  The furniture and decorations haven't changed EVER; and won't until they break.
author: Patrick A.

description: Sounded great from the Yelp review so i thought i'd try it.  Walked in, nobody acknowledged my presence, and the place STANK.  Turned around and went elsewhere.  This place seriously needs Robert Irvine!
author: Steve W.

description:
After seeing all the great reviews on here, we had to try this place out.  We were seeing a show at the Post Street Theatre, so the location was right. 

Warm goat cheese salad...great.  Cream of asparagus soup...great.  Fried chicken with country gravy and chive mashed potatoes...greeeeeeeeeeeat.  They also had the most tender ribs on special with this fabulous homemade bbq sauce.  I don't even like bbq sauce (boyfriend got them) but I kept sneaking bites.  

Our waiter was super friendly, the portions are ample, and the prices are remarkable reasonable ($15 for my chicken dinner, $18 for the ribs special).  We loved that the waiter included prices in his recitation of the specials...no one ever does that! 

It was a very pleasant dining experience and I will most definitely come back again.
author: Meghan P.

description:
Walking into the White Horse is like walking into a pub in London except you don't have to dodge puddles of puke to get inside, which is nice.  After our lovely experience at the SF Playhouse the BF and I ended up here for a post-show drink.  

Sal the bartender ("He's a legend in this city" a regular informs us) was attentive and gracious and made the perfect Seven & 7 according to the BF.  And he didn't even bat an eye when I spilled said Seven & 7 all over the bar.  (I was having quite the night.)  He just smiled, said "No problem!" and made another one which the BF wisely moved as far away from me as possible.  

We even got to meet some of the actors from the play we had just seen.  Apparently they like to come here for a post-show cocktail, too.  And you know that's really saying something 'cause people in "the business" know where all the best places are.  

Definitely worth checking out!
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
White Horse Tavern is great.  The small bar up front has friendly service.  We were welcomed with a smile and a hello.  I was a bit surprised by the $8 per drink price (not expensive, but more than I expected), but they were well-made (although I think all manhattans should have bitters) and reasonably portioned at 4 ounces or so (as compared to those super-sized portions typical elsewhere).  

White Horse has an old-school feel.  The interior is what I'd imagine an old English pub to look like.  The furniture is well crafted (if not entirely comfortable).  And it's quiet.  While it was mostly empty when we were there (on a Friday night), I couldn't imagine it being very loud even when it's full.  Conversation is very easy.  

Despite an "it's your grandfather's restaurant" vibe, the food is good steak & potatoes stuff.  I had the filet mignon.  The meat tasted great--well seasoned and cooked.  Try the crab cakes.

Service is very friendly and not overly formal--actually, quite casual.  There was only one server while we were there, but she didn't ignore us or leave us hanging.  

Downtown, easily accessed by transit and near nightlife, White Horse is definitely worth a try.
author: QuodE D.

description:
If you've been in this area around 8 or 9 p.m. and are in search of a decent "steak and potatoes" type of meal (or any kind of meal, for that matter),  you'll know how hard it is to find a table somewhere.

After popping into every restaurant with the "if it ain't busy we'll stay, but I'm hungry and want to eat NOW" game plan, we finally said forget it and headed for the pizzeria...until we passed the White Horse.

I can't imagine how many times I've walked by there during the day, looking at the menu and thinking "Hmm, I should go there sometime," but never thinking about it when I'm on a quest  for a simple dinner.

I won't make that mistake again.

Of course, I got a seat immediately. The menu is totally of the "meat and potatoes" variety. Prices are awesome. And the food is actually pretty good (despite not having any major expectations).
author: Derek R.

description:
My little old English lady friend from Sheffield introduced me to this place, and I've loved it ever since. She came to San Francisco in 60's and worked for many years at the Beresford. The place looks like an olde English pub because the owners from the UK brought all that stuff over and decorated themselves. The beautiful handmade woodwork and British antiques and pictures add to the warm ambiance.

The food is always very good, and one of the best bargains in this whole neighborhood. The staff is impeccable.

I still eat here several times a year. It gives me a warm fuzzy feeling, inside and out. Let's just hope the owners don't sell this building to the Academy of Art  College so Elisa and her crew can rape another beautiful old place in this neighborhood.
author: stephan k.

description: Taken here by a business associate.  I'm a longtime fan of the White Horse in the West Village so was amused by the name.  Was more amused at the nice whiskey pours.  Good drinking bar.
author: Kent K.

description: Went here for happy hour, their drink prices are mediocre but they have free hot dogs and popcorn so that makes up for it. I think they are currently remodeling the kitchen so the restaurant is not open right now and the bathrooms are located in hotel rooms, which is kind of awkward. In general it was a pleasant experience. I dig the vibe here and will be coming back to enjoy the awesome decor.
author: Jacquelyn T.

description: I was a bit disappointed in their beer selection for a pub. I scheduled to meet a friend there for dinner, and found out after I ordered my beer that the restaurant we indefinitely closed. I was annoyed. I liked their free peanuts.
author: Tracy C.

description: This is a nice little english pub. Its not going to be your everyday sports bar as theres not a TV. But its a great place to come and just relax. Its always pretty busy and packed as ive seen it. The selection is pretty good and they serve free pub mix and popcorn. Gonna make this place a regular.
author: Toby H.

description:
We're big fans of the White Horse. Before a show or after a show our audiences love going there for a cocktail or nightcap. Classic tavern!

Lori is our favorite bartender who works Saturday night. 

At first it feels like an over the top homage to a typical English pub, until we brought an English friend of ours to the tavern after one of ours shows. He said it looked exactly like his local pub outside London, except his pub had lower ceilings!

Go! OH, currently they're renovating their kitchen and serving free Hot Dogs -- that are actually tasty! (But you don't go there for the food!)
author: Improv S.

description:
How I have only just discovered this place is beyond me. I live and work blocks from here and stumbled across it after deciding not to deal with the Cantina bar crowd Saturday night. Just wanted a nice pub where you could hear your companion and have a beer. Found it. Sal the bartender is adorable and the other staff Steve and Laurie are awesome. What started off as a couple of beers ended up being more drinks and then dinner. The atmosphere was casual and comfortable. No pretentious a-holes and no drunk biotches puking in the bathroom (sorry that's another review that I have to write another time). 

I'm getting off topic though. The food: everything on the menu was less than $20. Where in all of San Francisco, let alone in Union Square can you find a meal for under $20? I'd say most of their dishes were in the low teens in fact. Decided to have the fried chicken because of course I'm obsessed with fried chicken. It was boneless, it was yummy, it was smothered in something that I'm sure went straight to my arse but who cares. I think I might go back this week for more. Heading to the gym tonight to make sure I can still fit in my jeans afterwards.
author: Heather L.

description:
THEIR DINING ROOM IS CLOSED UNTIL MID-FEBRUARY

The bartender was very nice and pulled a good pint, but we were a little disappointed by the lack of food (other than a bowl of free tasty-style snacks).  He said the dining room is closed for a month or so for renovations, but will be open in March at the latest for the British tourists.

I'll be back for the Fillet!
author: Jesse E.

description: Ran into this place by luck, but SO HAPPY about it, cause all the other clubs and bars were so crowded, charging up the butt cover charges, long lines... and bam out of nowhere we saw this place, it was like a ray of sunshine shining through the dark clouds! GREAT chill place, ALL you can eat popcorn, and they played Matchbox Twenty - 3am. LOVE IT! CHEAP $4 pints that are on tap (Stella and Bass). SUPER nice and friendly bartender. Definitely wouldn't mind coming back here!
author: Irene L.

description:
Not only does this place look like it belongs in England, but it also makes you feel like you're in England.  8:00 pm on a Wednesday night I'm sitting at the bar and the place is packed with British tourists.  I think that's about as close I'll ever get to the British Isles.

Drinks were good and my friend got the fillet Mignon which was under $20.
author: Corey V.

description: Came in here after a friends' wedding next door at the Marine Memorial Club. All I remember is that everyone was having a great time. Other than that the night's a blur. Oh and I vaguely remember a bunch of us kept singing that song " White Horse". Good times
author: Nick R.

description:
You know the really terrible feeling you get when you realize that you forgot Mom's birthday last week and that Mother's Day was actually yesterday, and not next week as you thought (OK, what can I say, that was a rough year....)?

That's how I just felt when I realized that I have never written a review for the White Horse. Bacchus is totally going to write me out of his will.

So, here I am to make amends - this review is mainly about the bar, but I won't totally ignore the restaurant either:
THE WHITE HORSE. For me, the place is home. Literally, I spend more time there than I spend awake at my own house. The bartenders are like family, Sal's the jovial Grandpa (well, except that he's always getting me drunk) and Lori is the really cool, older sister who always has a good book recommendation at hand. Going to the White Horse is like going home for comfy Sunday family night, full of love, laughter and affection, except that at the Horse, I get to be drunk, belligerent and naughty too. OK, so it is exactly like family night...

But even if you don't work around the corner and happen to finish your day there three times a week, you can still expect the following:
* nicest bartenders on the planet

* two beers on tap - yes, that's not much for a pub, but they stand behind that decision with such charm, you forgive them. And with Stella and Bass, two beers on tap is just fine.

* good, cheap, strong cocktails. And they get stronger the better you get to know Sal, so beware!

* free pretzels and peanuts to your hearts' desire

* oh, and if you're so inclined, you can also heave "real" dinner there. Food is very traditional and all the meat is really yummy. Pasta isn't really their forte, and Light Cuisine hasn't made it's way through the red double doors yet.

Five gushy, mushy, loving and drunk stars - check out the most unpretentious, calm and friendly place in all of Downtown/Union Square. I'm the noisy, drunk European in the back room, don't mind me.
author: Tatjana G.

description: White Horse is a lovely little pub.  For anyone who has spent some time in London at some of the local pubs will love White Horse -- the vibe is cozy and relaxed.  Free hot dogs, and now free popcorn, are wonderful little treats and I get a kick out of the bartenders.  Some people think that only two beers on tap (bass & stella) is lame but I'd rather have two fresh beers on tap then be at a place that rarely changes out their taps, and beer tastes like ick, because they have so many choices. So White Horse is lovely and highly recommended by locals. Cheers!
author: Sam E.

description: Only two beers on tap: Stella and Bass. I went with the latter. $4. Nice. Decent atmosphere.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Lucky me, living around the corner from the White Horse. A little cleaner than my normal dive, but they make up for that by having free hot dogs seemingly all the time, hot water handy for the strong and soothing hot toddies, and the perfect amount of bartender conversation, I.e. As much or as little as you want. Never empty and never overcrowded. I heart the WH.
author: erica d.

description:
Oh this place succeeds on charm. 

In the mood for a Bass or Stella? Perfect. Because those are the only two beers on tap. I wish the fake hand pumps at the bar were real, I wish I were really in London, but here's a free hot dog to sooth you, and how about some popcorn too?

This place is super cozy, it really does remind me of a simple local pub in London (minus the beer selection). Fake fireplace, wood beams and British relics everywhere. The restaurant itself has been closed/under renovation for a while, maybe when it's open again I'll be able to get a proper meat pie... until then I'll dream by the fireplace with a nice Bass.
author: riah g.

description: What a great find. Thanks yelp! Nice bartender with a little bit of an older crowd. Will definitely be back. One note, though, the kitchen is closed for remodeling. Bartender couldn't/wouldn't say when it would be open again. Free hotdogs, though!
author: Lloyd B.

description: I enjoyed this place. Cozy. Quiet. Fireplace. The ambiance made me feel like I was visiting a New England Tavern. Definitely a  locals bar with most of the traffic coming from the local neighborhood and theater goers. True, the drinks are "cheap" (for SF) and the wine list average at best but I enjoyed the atmosphere. A nice place for an after dinner drink and conversation.
author: M D.

description: Located in the Beresford Hotel, it has a separate entrance reminiscent of an English pub. The resemblance continues inside, with beamed ceilings and wood-panelled walls, although the red vinyl banquette lining one side of the room seems more diner than Dover. For more than twenty years, they've been serving excellent steaks, chops, and prime rib in the British tradition, along with an eclectic assortment of international dishes, at ridiculously low prices. A huge slab of tender prime rib, served with soup or a mixed green salad, fresh vegetables, baked potato, Yorkshire pudding, and coffee or tea, is only $16.95. Linguini with prawns or chicken, tossed with fresh spinach, tomatoes, and basil pesto, is $11.50. And this isn't cafeteria-style cooking, either. Other recommended dishes include a maple-cured pork chop with homemade ginger apple sauce and wild rice, grilled salmon with Tobiko caviar and tarragon tartar sauce, Southern fried chicken with country gravy and mashed potatoes, and an outstanding meat loaf with house-made ketchup and chive-mashed potatoes. Dessert selections change frequently, but if the pumpkin cheesecake is on the menu, be sure to order it. Service is friendly and efficient.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I finally brought a crew of friends in here- along with my visiting parents. Everyone was pretty much a 4-star smackin' happy with the comfort food and cutesy atmosphere feelin' vibe. Great decor, and the Brits love to come here - LOVE TO. They stay in the hotel, and they soak up the wooden bar up front, along with the bartender, Sal, who's about 80 years old and more chipper than Britney Spears on a crack-binge. He moves kinda slow, but has a steady pour on the hard licks, and can keep up with the college crowd that rolls in from 11-1 on the weekends. The meal was very affordable, and the party was happy. The shrimp cocktail was a popular appetizer in our group and the maple cured pork chop, filet mignon and warm goat cheese salad were entree winners. The service is keen and attentive.
author: Braden B.

description: Every time I come to San Francisco I get quite drunk at the White Horse.  Good, friendly crowd, nice barkeep.  Hooray!
author: Will T.

description: I'm going to pass judgment even though they're renovating. Two beers on tap? Seriously? You call yourself a tavern???? There were three old ladies at the bar chattering and it was empty--there wasn't even a hum of terrible music. Maybe I'm missing something, or cause it was rainy outside--not sure but I don't really ever plan on going back.
author: Krystha B.

description: Reasonably friendly bartender, free popcorn, a few good microbrews on tap, lively but not too bro.
author: Travis L.

description:
What a great place for the money! I had the fillet, the wife had the Salmon, we had wine and the bill with tax and tip was 68 bucks! That aint bad in Union Square for a very good meal. It aint a five star joint but its a good four star with 2 star prices!!! I recommend this place to anyone who has Moet tastes but a Korbel pocket book!
Steve
Tuolumne, CA
author: Steve W.

description: Come on, how does an English style pub get by with only 2 beers on tap, Bass Ale and I think the other one was Stella?   I popped in there on Saturday night to esape the crowd at the Cellar.  White Horse has great decor and ambience and it could be a great pub, but ya gotta have some good English brews (beers & ales) on tap!!!!!  Until that happens, I'll not return.
author: Sean L.

description: Why I never knew about this place until a few days ago, I don't know, but I'm glad I found out about it. Comfy tavern-like low key place to have a whiskey and water. Fun place to chill after a night of performing on stage and they give out free hot dogs! Keep going for a while and the bartender will remember you.
author: Farah S.

description: Beer, whiskey, peanuts and pretzels...an influx of actors around 11 p.m. and friendly bartenders. Not a bad way to spend an evening.
author: carrie c.

description: What a great little secret on Sutter.  A tiny doorway yields a sweet reward for those walking through the Theatre District and past the hotels in this neighborhood.  The restaurant is further back, but a tiny, yet cozy pub beckons those who wander in to stay for a round of English beers or a glass of wine.  Pub food is offered on Mondays and the bartenders I have seen are super friendly.  With the authentic feel, the foreign tourists and the wood-beamed walls, this place is a great location to knock back a few downtown without feeling like you are hanging out with the fanny pack crowd.
author: Taylor P.

description:
After an amazing first date with a beautiful young lady at Nick's Crispy Tacos, I chose White Horse as the location for our second date.  I don't remember my exact thought process in choosing this establishment, but I think it was the following quote from one of the reviews that pushed me over the edge:  "your Grandfathers restaurant and smells like old people."  In addition, the place received positive reviews and seemed like a unique and interesting place to check out.  

Due to a game of kickball and several intense rounds of Flip-Cup the previous night, I was understandably exhausted all day leading up to the date.  Yet, after laying eyes on my Date's pretty face and soaking in her positive vibes, I was instantly energized and excited for our adventure into this mysterious dining establishment.  

The restaurant didn't exactly smell like old people...more of a combination of an antique store and a dusty attic.  The décor conjured up images of a regal family dining room in England (not that I've ever been there, but that's how I imagine it).   The friendly waitress seated us at a table with booth seating on one side and chair seating on the other.  The seating arrangement discrepancy caused my Date to tower over me which threw off our vibe completely.  We remedied this situation by taking it upon ourselves to cozy into the corner booth (the restaurant was empty).  We ordered some drinks and began to relax and soak in the vibes of this rustic establishment.  After a few drinks and much debate over what to order, my Date got some sort of fish dish and I got a steak.  Both were reasonably priced and delicious.  The atmosphere was very cozy and extremely quiet.  The only other people in the place were these two older women who sat in close proximity to us and were probably horrified at our conversation which consisted of college drinking stores, sexual innuendo and other inappropriate subjects.  

This is not the most happening spot in the city, but if you're looking for a quiet, cozy and unique spot to enjoy some reasonably priced fine dining, the White Horse is a great choice.  It is also a great place to wine and dine potential girlfriends: it worked perfectly for me.
author: Patrick N.

description: Delicious.  Great rec from Yelp.  We were looking for a dinner spot before this crazy play at the ACT and decided to give it a shot.  I read the filet was excellent and it did not disappoint.  The oil in the sauce started to separate a little during my meal but I left no food on my plate so that tells you how much it bothered me!  They don't serve fancy frou frou drinks so don't try to order them and the service is decent - no over the top professional wait staff but it's definitely worth the $17 filet mignon!  Give it a try!
author: Cindy F.

description:
First I need to complain about something (real briefly) then I need to tell you how great this pub is. The complaint is not about the pub.

I called the number that's  posted for the tavern - today is 1/29/11 -to ask a question. The man that answered had a thick possibly Indian accent, he said the tavern had been closed for over a year! I couldn't believe it! I wasn't satisfied so I called the hotel - wow, double whammy! I asked if it was true that the pub had closed, this guy didn't know there was a pub connected to the hotel! He said there's a bar that opens at 5:00, I said ok, great, that would be the English pub right? He said he didn't know if it was an English style pub, it was just a bar. Anyway, I'm posting this because if employees who work for the hotel are telling people that the pub is closed - that's bad for business! It's such a great place here in the city that I was in denial and kept searching for more info to find out if it actually was closed. Anyhoo, I'm going there tonight to confirm it's open and to let anyone else know that if you call there and are told it's closed, it might not be the case! Too bad the bar doesn't have it's own phone number.

Now for a quick review of the pub - I haven't been there in a while, obviously! But the place is great! Great prices and great atmosphere, you can easily feel the experience one has of actually being in an old English  pub -  contryside or Londonside! On this drizzly day, I can't wait to go there for a pint and a scotch and a  little escape to the far off English countryside!! This place can NEVER close down, it's wonderful! Friendly, fun, full of atmosphere!

I will post tomorrow to confirm they are still open! And I plan to tell the bartender to have a talk with the hotel staff so they know there is a bar named White Horse attached to the hotel they are working at! ???
author: lydacious p.

description: Don't go here for the kidney pie, because that was years ago...BUT go to the pub ... for your craving for a good ol' PIMMS cup! One of the last for former Anglophiles that can't forget that one last drink before heading out for Indja..go West or is that East? ....tally ho.
author: miriam b.

description: This was a great surprise. The crab cake salad has a tasty dressing. The filet was perfectly cooked. And the pie seemed homemade with some really good ice cream. I'm planning on going back to try the fried chicken.
author: Angela K.

description:
my friend and i staggered out of the surreal and hilarious taping of conan o'brien and wandered the streets in search of a bar. seriously wandered-- this happens to us all the time, so we prepared for our usual 30 min of confusion until we stumbled upon the white horse.

it was happy hour and so there were only a few patrons. the service was friendly and the beers a standard happy-hour-happy price. i had a stella which sadly was NOT served in an exciting glass though it was quite fresh and went down smoothly. 

my only qualm about the white horse? we went in because it had free appetizers...sadly, they presented NO vegetarian options. it's san francisco!! there should be at least one free vegetarian option, even at a british pub...
author: Yaamini R.

description: This restaurant need some serious re-decoration. There was only one other table taken at 7:30 on a Thursday night. My meal looked atrocious and tasted just as horrible. The food was bland, unappealing, and presentation was utterly lacking.
author: Juliet H.

description: I dislike faux English taverns at the best of times but this place takes the biscuit. I sat down at the bar waiting to be served whilst the barmaid chatted endlessly to another customer. Another guy sat at the bar next to me and she automatically served him, continued to ignore me, and went back to chatting to her friends. Needless to say I left. You don't want to pay good custom to a bitch like that.
author: Fiona T.

description: Fun and efficient place to grab a drink with your buddies and be totally comfortable. No losers lacking bar etiquette or fashion freaks cramping your style in this cool pub. Free pretzels too....SOLD!
author: Stacy T.

description: A great solid restaurant with a very reasonable menu.  The food was great, all four of us had a different entrée and shared.  Pasta was cooked just right with tons of shrimp, lamb was perfect, chicken was great and the ribs were super.  The mashed potatoes were possibly the best we have ever had.  All at a very reasonable rate.  Very convenient location and great service.
author: Bruce M.

description: I stopped in here one night for drinks with a friend who had recently moved here from England.  Naturally, one of the first comments he made was "This is quite English, really" -- because you definitely feel as though you've stepped into some Tudor structure.  We didn't come for the food, just for drinks, so we sat in the bar area.  The bartender had to be one of the oldest bartenders in San Francisco, but he was quite friendly and helpful.  We were the youngest people in the bar area by about 20 years, but no matter -- it felt very neighborhoody, especially since I grew up going to bar/restaurants (or pubs) rather often with my parents.  Drinks were good, atmosphere was rather impressive/interesting/surreal, and prices were normal.  Minus 1 star for not being somewhere I'd want to go every night.
author: Casey S.

description:
When I crossed over the threshold to the White Horse Tavern and Restaurant, I somehow stepped into old England. This little restaurant is a charming gem in the city if you want a slow night of decent food at reasonable prices.

My date and I were seated in the dining room which had only 1 server for 10 or so tables. Based on the reviews I'd read, I was surprised that there weren't many more people in the dining room. Both of us ordered the renowned ($18!) filet mignon. I also had a starter of goat cheese salad with roasted red peppers and greens. The salad was good - the cheese pungent with a crusty skin - but slightly overdressed by the balsamic vinaigrette. The star of the meal really was the filet, which, for me, was cooked a perfect rare. The mushroom, shallot, and cabernet sauce was rich and spot-on in flavor (it may be slightly too salty for some), and it balanced perfectly with the sauteed vegetables, the chives mashed potatoes, and the tender meat. I swabbed the plate clean of every last drop of the delicious sauce with the rest of the plate. I would have picked up the plate and licked it clean had there not been a proper English couple seated next to us (with accents and all; I told you...old England!). 

It's not just the $18 filet mignon and the delectable sauce. It's not just the menu that probably hasn't been changed and has been perfected for decades. It's not just the feeling of entering another world, where everything is slower and easier. It's everything rolled up together into an unassuming package that makes White House Tavern & Restaurant such a winner.
author: Ian S.

description: We stumbled on this place over a year ago. If your looking for character and old world charm this is the place. The first time we dined here we were almost afraid of what the food was going to be like due to the low prices. Every item we have tried has been fantastic. If I lived in the city I would be dining here at least once a week as the service has always been fantastic. Steve is a wonderful waiter and will make sure you have a great dining experience. If your looking for a place out of the ordinary this is it!
author: KJ J.

description: simple, delicious, and unpretentious.  Friendly wait staff and amazing food.  It's one of those places that rarely exist anymore, especially in SF.  Just kind of old timey and precious.  I got the rack of lamb which which was simple and amazing.  The asparagus soup was also delicious, mmmm.  I need to go back and try the rest of their menu, looking forward to the fried chicken and filet mignon.
author: Sophie P.

description: terrific food, terrific service, and even got a glass of red wine for free.  highly recommended for steak that will not break the bank.
author: Teddie H.

description:
This placed sure did not look attractive from the outside nor did it look good in the inside but the food is sure good.  

They recommended the filet mignon and it was better than some of the steakhouses.  It was tender and juicy and my tummy was satisfied.
author: kenny l.

description: amazingly large fake fireplace, horsey photos on the wall, homemade sangria in a large tupperware behind the bar, complimentary hot dogs.... good times.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: i don't know anything about the restaurant but the pub in the front is a great little secret.  not quite sure if i should be sharing... i work next door to this place and it makes for a great wind down after work.  they have a little free food for happy hour on mondays too. the bartender on monday nights is the best (tip her well).  if you are looking to hang out with young people or pick up someone this is definitely not the place for you.  it is the farthest from hip that you can get.  the patrons are a mix of old time locals, foreigners staying in the hotel, and actors from all of the theaters in the neighborhood.  the place is a dead ringer for an old english pub. the only reason i'm not giving it 5 stars is because i've never eaten the food.
author: amanda w.

description: My husband and I haven't been here for a few years, but I think we'll go again.  A nice place and reasonable.  It's not fancy but they were always very on top of things.  Sort of funny story...we took my father in law, who was a fussy guy there and it was a hassle to get him over there because he wasn't easy to trek around, old and senile as he was.  So we got him there like I think it was Father's Day or something, and he first said "you went to all this trouble to bring me HERE?, shit" in a real loud voice.  I think he was expecting some place like Harris' or something which this place isn't, and anyway, after that opening line, he orders a steak, and he starts complaining the moment the gets it "it's tough! what kind of place did you bring me!".. well the truth is, the steak was probably just fine, but the waiter took it back and brought him a new one no charge. Personally I felt like having a napkin over my head, but the waiter was kind and patient.  That's the point, they were nice about the old guy and didn't blink and eye.  I liked every meal I had there, must go back ... now that the father in law has passed on to his reward.
author: Sarah H.

description: Went to this spot last Friday with one of my good buddies..the place looks ancient, but clean. Had the filet mignon ($17.95!) and a Caesar Salar ($5.95)...both REALLY good. Definitely would go back...
author: Steve K.

description: I liked this place--pleasantly Old World without feeling Disney-fied, good staff, pleasant food, and relatively inexpensive. I simply wish they'd close the curtain on the entrance to the kitchen. The noise and glare from the kitchen diminished the coziness of the room. If you go be sure to request a table as far from the kitchen as possible.
author: Eileen M.

description: This is one of those restaurants you don't hear about but wonder why.  The food was wonderful, service great, prices very reasonable and the atmosphere offered that "ole time San Francisco" feeling.  Truly was a great night out for dinner.
author: Debra B.
